title: The Project
content: The [Disney Interactive Group](http://www.disney.co.jp/mobile/s-style/service.html) produces branded, Japanese mobile experiences by partnering with service carriers like SoftBank and DoCoMo.

A contract renewal gave our team the opportunity to expand our subscription-based mobile services on SoftBank. I collaborated with a lean, in-house team on everything from product conceptualization to user experience patterns and definition of guidelines.

caption: Solution
title: The Product
content: In May 2015, we launched the [Disney Style Home Launcher](http://www.disney.co.jp/mobile/s-style/service.html). This launcher featured themed bundles of immersive home screen pages that also served as utility widgets like Calendar and Clock.
We collaborated with popular Japanese artists to provide a rich library of themed bundles. You can check out a promotional video for the service [here](https://youtu.be/9Vl0MVpXhzk).
imgCaption: Home screen pages in the Mickey's Paper World themed bundle

caption: The Big Picture
title: Goals
content: The decision to build a home launcher was rooted deeply in market research. SoftBank users wanted offerings as rich as DoCoMo's, which had smartphones with Disney themed hardware and software. In addition to targeting our _yafu_ (young adult female) audience, the product also had to provide

caption: Trust the Process
title: Deciding on a Concept
content: Our initial set of concepts ranged from copying existing products to science fiction-esque ideas. Starting broad and low fidelity helped us understand our technical constraints and product principles.
Ultimately, we needed to deliver on entertainment, our strength, rather than something left-field like new technology. The final concept highlighted simplicity and native functionality.
imgCaption: Sketches and wireframes of early concepts

caption: Design Decisions
title: Core Navigation and Customization
content: We designed everything in the launcher to highlight the immersive home pages.
To place focus on the artwork, we introduced a Mickey Home button. This let docked apps, like Messages, be accessible without cluttering the page.
Access to native apps was just a long tap away from any home screen widget. This let the home launcher be both useful and entertaining.
Last but not least, how someone organizes their phone is extremely personal. That's why we made sure that users could edit their home page widgets and add completely customizable pages.
alts: Clock widget and list of alarms
imgCaption: Clock app widget (left) and page and widget customization (right)

caption: Thanks for the Feedback
title: Usability Testing
content: A few weeks before launch, we conducted usability studies. The studies revealed that users had a hard time distinguishing tap targets from illustrative elements. To mitigate this, I introduced
1. **guidelines for artists**, which prevent the artwork from interfering with interactive elements, and
2. **an onboarding flow**, which gave users the opportunity to learn about launcher in a guided fashion.
imgCaption: Onboarding flow that was added based on usability feedback

caption: Product in the Wild
title: Release & Sunset
content: Disney Style Home Launcher was released with a SoftBank campaign in May 2015. The service [operated successfully](https://kyodonewsprwire.jp/release/201603178993) for 3 years, with the seasonal bundles gaining _yafu_ popularity.
In December 2018, SoftBank and Disney parted ways and the Disney Style Home Launcher was sunsetted.
